holidays.name: National Threading the Needle Day
holidays.description: Celebrate the tiny art of threading a needle ‚Äî an oddly satisfying and surprisingly tricky task! Perfect for crafters and anyone who enjoys a good close-up challenge.
holidays.origin: Likely started by sewing enthusiasts and crafters to honor skill and patience involved in needle threading.
holidays.funFact: Threading a needle is so satisfying that some people use it as a calming activity to improve concentration and reduce stress.

holidays.name: Gastronomy Exploration Day
holidays.description: A quirky unofficial holiday encouraging adventurous eaters to try something new and weird food-wise on July 25th.
holidays.origin: Originated in foodie circles to promote culinary curiosity and cultural food exploration.
holidays.funFact: Every year on this day, people share pictures of their weirdest food finds on social media, from fried insects to bizarre desserts.

holidays.name: Morse Code Day
holidays.description: Celebrate the invention of Morse code by Samuel Morse, the early communication breakthrough using dots and dashes.
holidays.origin: Commemorates the birthday of Samuel Morse (April 27, but observance chosen differently by enthusiasts) or important dates related to Morse code.
holidays.funFact: Morse code was used extensively during World War II and is still used by amateur radio operators worldwide today.

holidays.name: Tell an Old Joke Day
holidays.description: A fun day to resurrect those classic, sometimes cringe-worthy old jokes from the past and share some laughs, groans, and eye rolls.
holidays.origin: Informal internet-born celebration to spread humor and nostalgia.
holidays.funFact: Many 'old jokes' date back decades or centuries and often reflect the social humor of their era!
